title: Rental market weakens following housing boom
text:
Rental markets have weakened during the past three months as demand struggles to soak up the excess supply created by high investor activity during the recent housing boom, the latest CoreLogic Quarterly Rental Review shows.

Nationally, rental rates dropped 0.3 per cent over the September quarter, reversing the 0.3 per cent gain recorded during the previous quarter.

Canberra recorded the biggest decline of 1.1 per cent, followed by Sydney which had a 1 per cent fall.

Regional markets fared better with a 0.3 per cent rise in rents, but rental growth has slowed compared with a year ago.

The drop in rental rates comes amid a stronger than expected recovery in the broader market where Sydney and Melbourne dwelling prices rose by 1.7 per cent in September.

Tim Lawless, head of research at CoreLogic, said the broad-based weakness in rental conditions was probably owing to a rise in rental supply after the surge in investment and residential construction activity through the previous housing boom.
description: Rental markets have weakened during the past three months as demand struggles to soak up the excess supply created by high investor activity during the recent housing boom
